originalText.text: Would have loved it if I could have actually found it! One of the hidden joints! Google maps put me right in front of the place bit couldn't find the entry! Need more signage!

text.text: Would have loved it if I could have actually found it! One of the hidden joints! Google maps put me right in front of the place bit couldn't find the entry! Need more signage!

originalText.text: It was very pretty and lots of fun. The restaurants there were VERY nice and the people there were very friendly, even if it's just to draw you in, it's nice to hear and see. The food smelled SO GOOD! It was a little on the expensive side, but the service is amazing we left in a good mood. I don't know how anyone couldn't leave in a good mood there. It's contagious.

text.text: It was very pretty and lots of fun. The restaurants there were VERY nice and the people there were very friendly, even if it's just to draw you in, it's nice to hear and see. The food smelled SO GOOD! It was a little on the expensive side, but the service is amazing we left in a good mood. I don't know how anyone couldn't leave in a good mood there. It's contagious.

originalText.text: Not only will you find lots of great Italian restaurants, but the restaurant facades are worth just looking at.  They have pillars, statues, and Italian features outside the restaurants.   So, there's no mistaking that great Italian fare is available.

text.text: Not only will you find lots of great Italian restaurants, but the restaurant facades are worth just looking at.  They have pillars, statues, and Italian features outside the restaurants.   So, there's no mistaking that great Italian fare is available.

originalText.text:
The most historically important site for my Culture Weekend to Italy Staycation:  Little Italy.  I couldn’t wait to hit this historical area, be inundated with Italian culture and transported to another place, but as I approached the area, I became distracted: that’s not Italian, that’s Chinese.  Okay, so Little Italy is being invaded by Chinatown, but the area is still very Italian.  There are Italian restaurants, shops and an Italian American Museum that I’d like to visit next time I tour the area.

As I approached Grand St, all I could remember was this excitement bubbling up inside of me, “we’re almost here“, I thought.  Conversely, as I walked down Grant St, not even what seemed to be four buildings in, all I could remember was this disappointment burrowing inside of me, “we’re now in Chinatown“, I thought.   I have nothing against Chinatown, but the sighting of a Chinese massage shop smack dab in the middle of Grand St. was an abrupt end to the vibe I was experiencing with the Italian storefronts.  That’s okay, I’ll just grab a cannoli from Emma & Angie’s Cannoli Shack; that will ease my pain.  And it did.

originalText.text: very italian!!!! try the various food there! Little Italy is right next to the Chinatown. You can see som many Italian restaurants here. I don't really like to food but I usually just like Asian food, so i would recommend everyone to visit and try the food
